Award.AwardTitle: A Molecular Link Between Actin and Exocytosis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Polarized growth of individual cells is a complex process integrating cellular metabolism events and the extracellular environment. Extension and shape changes are frequently accompanied with deposition of material into their extracellular environments. In plants, cells also build a network of carbohydrate polymers that act as a rigid barrier, known as the cell wall. Plant cells grow by building new cell wall material and plant cell shape is intimately linked with how this material is deposited on the outside of the cell. This project will work to elucidate the link between delivery of cell wall material and the cell's internal network of dynamic filaments known as the cytoskeleton. In particular the PI will use sophisticated light microscope imaging methods to test the hypothesis that formin proteins are critical for targeting actin assembly processes that initiate cell wall material exocytosis. Although it is known that cell growth and the cytoskeleton are intimately connected, a detailed mechanistic understanding of this coupling remains to be elucidated. This project will take advantage of moss, a simple, genetically tractable plant model system, to address this fundamental cell biological question.

Broader Impacts: The investigator will broaden the impacts of the proposed research by providing resources and expertise to the plant research community, training of undergraduates and underrepresented minorities, and incorporating aspects of the project in undergraduate education. The moss model system is ideally suited for undergraduate laboratory experiences. Therefore, the investigator will also develop a project-based laboratory course wherein students perform RNA-induced silencing experiments to analyze the function of individual genes and their roles in cell growth. Additionally, a summer laboratory module offered through the STEM Diversity Institute at U. Mass will aim to increase participation and recruitment of underrepresented minorities. Course materials from the summer module will be distributed to underrepresented faculty at partner institutions to facilitate implementation of similar courses. Incorporating faculty and students in this endeavor will contribute to increasing diversity in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term goal of this project is to understand how molecules within cells pattern the extracellular environment, ultimately determining tissue morphology. The research in this project focused on a simple elongated cell shape that naturally occurs in the ephemeral juvenile tissues of mosses. As a plant, moss builds a cell wall around each cell and the shape of that wall dictates the shape of the cell and tissue. Secretion of either flexible or rigid materials, or enzymes that can alter the rigidity of the wall is absolutely essential for this process. However, how the cell coordinates delivery of different cargo to different regions of the cell is a fundamental and outstanding question in cell biology.

Cargo delivery is a complex intracellular process that culminates with the merging of small membrane-bound cargo-carrying compartments with the outer membrane of the cell. This fusion event allows the contents of the cargo to be expelled into the extracellular environment. Fusion is mediated by complexes of proteins that tether the compartments to the membrane. This proposal identified a unique protein, named formin1F, found only in mosses that contains two functional domains: one domain acts together with the tethering complex and the other interacts with an intracellular dynamic filamentous network that organizes the interior of the cell. The existence of this unique protein suggested that membrane tethering may be directly linked to innate organizational forces in the cell. The research supported by this award demonstrated that formin1F is found both at sites of compartment tethering and along the dynamic filamentous network. Furthermore, without formin1F cells were unable to survive, suggesting that connecting tethering with intracellular organization is essential for cell viability. Intriguingly, in the absence of formin1F it was possible to restore cell viability by providing the tethering and intracellular organization activities of formin1F on separate proteins, suggesting that these activities do not need to exist on the same protein, but rather both activities must be present in the cell to restore function. It is possible that in mosses, the fusion of these activities onto one protein made the process more efficient but in other organisms these activities are still linked. These studies provided novel insights into the evolution of a novel protein domain configuration within the mosses as well as evidence for direct linkage between tethering and intracellular organization.

Formin2A is a related protein that only contains the filament network interacting domain. Formin2A is a critical regulator of specialized cargo delivery. Without formin2A, cells swell uniformly into spheres instead of elongated tubes. Research supported by this award found that formin2A is more closely linked with membrane recycling, rather than membrane tethering and delivery.  This award provided evidence for two critical pathways in cells: one for general cargo delivery, which is essential for viability and one for membrane recycling, which is critical for determining cell shape.

This award supported undergraduate training in a number of settings. In a classroom lab setting, students were given a semester-long research project where they learned to use modern molecular tools to ask how proteins localize in the cell. In the PI?s research lab, undergraduate researchers were paired with graduate or postdoctoral mentors and carried out research projects that supported the overall findings of the award. The award also supported outreach activities to middle schools introducing students to high-end microscopy, DNA isolation, as well as questions that are asked in cell biology research. Graduate student and postdoctoral training were fundamental aspects of the research supported by this award. In addition to research, students and postdocs participated in mentoring in lab and classroom settings as well as during outreach to middle schools.
